article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on advanced control of aerospace vehicles

abstract.p: In this paper, we will apply a switching fault-tolerant control approach to an air-breathing hypersonic vehicle subject to time-varying actuator and sensor faults. The faults under consideration include loss of effectiveness of the actuators and sensors. Possible fault scenarios are categorized into different fault cases based on the fault type and its location. For each case, a parameter-dependent (or constant gain) fault-tolerant control controller is designed to stabilize the faulty system with an optimal controlled performance. The synthesis condition of each local fault-tolerant control law is formulated in terms of linear matrix inequalities. To achieve both local optimal performance and switching stability, Youla parameterization of each individual local fault-tolerant control controller is performed and the result is applied to the closed-loop system. The quadratic stability of a fast switching closed-loop system is guaranteed by a common Lyapunov function. Simulation results based on the non-linear flexible hypersonic vehicle model and fault-tolerant linear-parameter-varying controllers are presented and the reults of these studies demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed switching fault-tolerant control approach for application to a hypersonic vehicle.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Air-breathing hypersonic vehicles (HSVs) may provide a more cost-effective way to access outer space and make intercontinental travel routine. Hypersonic flight is defined as occuring at a speed of at least five times that of sound. To achieve sustainable hypersonic flight in the atmosphere, an air-breathing HSV requires a scramjet propulsion system that is highly integrated with the airframe. Moreover, the vehicle will need to be light in weight and its flexible structure will have to be able to introduce elastic effects at low natural frequencies during flight.

The longitudinal motion dynamics of a HSV have been reported in the literature1–4 and the modeling and control problems of HSVs have been discussed. The main challenges in hypersonic modeling include the strong interactions between the aerodynamics and propulsion system, as well as the coupling between the rigid-body accelerations and flexible body dynamics. Newtonian impact theory was used to determine the pressure distributions over the vehicle in the earliest studies on modeling air-breathing HSVs.1 The pressures are dependent on the vehicle’s Mach number, free-stream pressure, angle of attack and vehicle geometry. Since this method is more suitable for the determination of the pressures on blunt shapes, oblique shock and Pradtl–Meyer theory was used in Bolender and Doman2 under the assumption that the airflow was quasi-steady. The longitudinal non-linear model derived in that paper could describe the complex flow properties by using flexible coupling effects in a scramjet-powered vehicle. It was further modified in several studies to capture the flow effect in the propulsive system4 and the governing flexible dynamics.3 Nevertheless, the quasi-steady assumption can be violated as a result of vehicle vibrations. To accurately describe the unsteady components of the flow field, piston theory was also applied in later aerodynamics modeling efforts.4,5

Similar to all other airplane and space vehicles, sensor/actuator failures are unavoidable in HSVs. Therefore, fault detection and isolation (FDI) and fault tolerant control (FTC) have become increasingly important for HSVs as a result of safety concerns. The study of FTC systems is motivated by the possibility of a faulty HSV being able to recover from damage and/or system faults. Typically, FTC involves automatically detecting and identifying the failed components and then reconfiguring the control law online in response to these decisions.6 FTC control approaches are broadly classified into two types: passive and active approaches. Passive FTC control is essentially a robust controller with a limited fault tolerant capacity.7 For small parameter and signal changes, such a robust controller is sufficient to achieve a passive form of fault tolerance. However, in many practical cases, the changes in system parameters caused by faults are relatively large. Then it becomes impossible to stabilize such a system with significant parameter changes, by means of a fixed robust controller. On the other hand, active FTC control has more flexibility and can allow the controller to adapt to different failure situations.8 Adaptive control techniques have been proposed to integrate fault identification and control reconfiguration together.9–12 However, adaptive control-based FTC systems can only handle constant fault signals. The gain-scheduling control approach13–15 has also been used recently for active FTC design.16,17 The robust FTC design proposed in Cai and Wu17 took into account imperfect estimation of fault effects which were provided by the fault diagnosis mechanism.

A faulty HSV subject to multiple actuator and sensor faults can be treated as a system switching among several different faults. Nevertheless, stability analysis is a fundamental and highly important issue in controlling switched and hybrid systems.18–21 The conditions of arbitrary switching between multiple linear time-invariant (LTI) controllers for a single linear plant were studied in Hespanha and Morse22 where the switching stability was achieved by swapping the Youla parameters of the controllers or resetting controller states at the switching instants. Other than resetting controller states, finding a common Lyapunov function also provides an effective way to achieve an arbitrary switching stability. Blanchini et al.23 proposed a separation principle that was used to derive the logic for observer-based compensators to allow arbitrary switching between LTI plants with both non-quadratic and quadratic common Lyapunov functions. When the requirement of the switching event is confined by a given switching logic such as switching in a dwell time or in a hysteresis region, the arbitrary switching conditions can become conservative. Then multiple Lyapunov functions need to be used to deal with constrained switching problems for both linear and non-linear systems.19,20,24,25 Other than the trivial monotonicity property, these Lyapunov functions can achieve switching stability by allowing a bounded growth of Lyapunov functions at some intervals in a suitable manner.19 For non-linear constrained switching systems, L2-gain analysis and H∞ control problems with piecewise continuous Lyapunov functions were studied in Zhao and Hill26. Along the line proposed by Hespanha and Morse22, a switching linear-parameter-varying (LPV) control approach has been developed in Rasmussen and Chang 27 to achieve switching stability and maintain local optimal performance. On the other hand, Lu and Wu28 studied the switching control of LPV systems using multiple parameter-dependent Lyapunov functions with both hysteresis switching and average dwell time logics.

This paper aims to accommodate multiple actuator and sensor faults for a challenging flexible air-breathing HSV using a switching FTC approach. Motivated by the switching LPV control strategy, we synthesize multiple gain-scheduling FTC controllers to accommodate different faults. Using parameter-dependent Lyapunov functions, a set of FTC controllers are designed to optimize the controlled performance for each fault scenario. To stabilize the system from arbitrary switching among faulty cases, Youla parameterizations of the FTC controllers are constructed such that a common quadratic Lyapunov function is shared by all the switching closed-loop systems. In comparison with previous FTC approaches, the proposed switching FTC scheme has the advantages that it can tolerate arbitrary switching actions among different fault scenarios and can achieve an optimal performance for individual faults of a flexible HSV. Moreover, the aircraft FTC problem has not been adequately addressed from a switching LPV control perspective.

This paper is organized as follows: the section “A flexible air-breathing HSV model” provides a flexible model of an air-breathing HSV. The section “Switching FTC approach” describes a switching faulty LPV control approach. The local FTC problem is formulated as a L2-gain optimization problem and its synthesis condition is provided. Moreover, a Youla parametrization of local FTC controllers is introduced which can maintain the local controlled performance. It is shown that the switching stability of multiple closed-loop systems is guaranteed using Youla parameterized controllers. The proposed switching FTC scheme is then applied to a faulty HSV in the section “Switching FTC design for HSV” for evaluation. Finally, conclusions are drawn in the final section.

sec.p: We now demonstrate the use of the proposed switching FTC algorithm on a flexible HSV under both multiple step and ramp tracking commands. The first considered operating scenario was to check the performance of switching FTC controllers under different trim conditions; the second scenario aimed to examine the switching FTC approach in a slow-varying operating environment.

Comparing with operation 1, there are smaller flexible effects in the ramp tracking operation (Figure 9).

We have also attempted to obtain a state-feedback robust FTC controller for fault control of a flexible HSV.16 Unlike the robust FTC algorithm, the switching FTC used a gain-scheduling output feedback control strategy to accommodate multiple fault cases on the same flight envelope. The tracking error of HSV switching control was smaller than for the robust FTC controller. Moreover, it can adjust to different actuator/sensor degradation levels without significantly degrading the control performance. It seems that the switching FTC algorithm is more suitable for FTC of a flexible HSV.

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: In this paper, we presented a switching FTC approach for a non-linear HSV under multiple time-varying actuator/sensor faults. For each fault case, a parameter-dependent FTC was designed to adjust its gains with respect to both system parameters and fault levels. The proposed FTC algorithm could accommodate two common fault types: actuator/sensor loss of effectiveness and sensor outage faults. The synthesis problem of local FTC controllers for each fault case was formulated as a L2-gain optimization problem which could be solved efficiently using LMI optimization techniques. A Youla parametrization of each FTC was performed so that the local controlled performance was preserved. The proposed switching FTC control scheme maintained switching stability during the change of fault type. It was shown that at any trim point, direct switching between local closed-loop systems with Youla parameterized FTC controllers can be stabilized by the existence of a common quadratic Lyapunov function. The proposed switching FTC approach was applied to the control problem of a flexible HSV. The simulation results obtained for a non-linear HSV model indicated that a LPV switching FTC could stabilize the vehicle and perform an altitude tracking task when the flexible HSV was subjected to canard and pitch sensor faults with variable degradation levels. It was found that the switching FTC approach could tolerate some degree of fault estimation error but was sensitive to altitude measurement noise. Moreover, frequent fault case switches can excite flexible modes and in turn destabilize the faulty HSV model. It suggested that the active FTC strategy is more suitable for hypersonic flight control than a passive control strategy.
